article.title: TRILEX and $GW$+EDMFT approach to $d$-wave superconductivity in the Hubbard model

choices: The definition of the tight-binding parameters on the square lattice
The evolution of the self-energy with temperature
The Fermi surface of the Hubbard model
The anomalous Green\'s function in the superconducting phase

multiple_choice_question.text: Which method in this figure includes vertex corrections in both local and non-local parts of the self-energy and polarization?
choices: GW
EDMFT
GW+EDMFT
TRILEX

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the bottom panel of this figure depict?
choices: The leading eigenvalue of the linearized gap equation
The superconducting critical temperature as a function of doping
The antiferromagnetic instability temperature
The density of states at the Fermi level

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main finding from the comparison of Tc(δ) in GW and GW+EDMFT methods at weak-coupling shown in this figure?
choices: Both methods significantly overestimate Tc compared to cluster DMFT calculations.
GW+EDMFT yields a much higher Tc than GW.
Both methods fail to capture the superconducting dome versus doping.
The optimal doping in both methods is around 12%.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the computation of TAF and Tc in GW for various t\', t\'\' and doping levels. What is the main observation regarding the relationship between TAF and Tc?
choices: The region of high Tc broadly coincides with the region of high TAF.
The maximum of Tc with respect to (t\', t\'\') at a fixed n always coincides with the maximum of TAF.
TAF is always higher than Tc for all values of t\', t\'\' and n.
The shape of the Fermi surface has no impact on the relationship between TAF and Tc.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information is conveyed by the gray contours in the insets of this figure?
choices: The temperature dependence of the superconducting gap.
The bare Fermi surfaces at different doping levels.
The spectral function at the antinodal wavevector.
The momentum dependence of the anomalous self-energy.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of this figure?
choices: To compare the critical temperatures obtained from GW and GW+EDMFT methods.
To illustrate the dependence of the superconducting gap on doping.
To summarize the observations from Figure 5 and highlight specific dispersions for further study.
To demonstrate the evolution of the spectral function with doping.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the superconducting temperatures at weak and strong couplings for two different dispersions. Which dispersion shows a significant enhancement of Tc at strong coupling?
choices: Dispersion B
Dispersion C

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key observation regarding the imaginary part of the normal self-energy (ImΣ) when transitioning from the normal phase to the superconducting phase in this figure?
choices: ImΣ increases significantly in both antinodal and nodal regions.
ImΣ is reduced at the antinode and slightly reduced at the node, with the difference roughly proportional to the anomalous self-energy in the superconducting phase.
ImΣ shows no change upon entering the superconducting phase.
ImΣ becomes strongly peaked at the antinodal wavevector.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the top panel of this figure show?
choices: The momentum dependence of the superconducting gap.
The evolution of the pairing amplitude with doping.
The spectral function at the antinodal wave vector for different doping levels.
The imaginary part of the normal self-energy in the superconducting phase.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which quantity in this figure exhibits a clear d-wave symmetry?
choices: The normal Green\'s function
The anomalous self-energy
The imaginary part of the normal self-energy
The non-local part of the spin boson propagator

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of extrapolating the leading eigenvalue λm (shown in the top panel) in this figure?
choices: To avoid the need for solving the impurity problem.
To determine the superconducting critical temperature despite the presence of the antiferromagnetic instability.
To improve the accuracy of the GW approximation.
To study the effect of local singlet physics on the superconducting phase.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main takeaway from this figure depicting the relationship between S, F, Σ and G?
choices: The anomalous self-energy S and the pairing amplitude F have the same order of magnitude.
The pairing amplitude F has a monotonous dependence on the anomalous self-energy S.
Strong normal self-energy and a large superconducting gap enhance both the Green\'s function and the pairing amplitude.
There exists a "sweet spot" where a small anomalous self-energy S produces a very strong superconducting pairing.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the extrapolation of λ(T) in different cases. What is the purpose of comparing λ(T) with max_q,iνm (Usp Psp_q (iνm))?
choices: To determine the accuracy of the fitting procedure.
To highlight the temperature at which the antiferromagnetic instability occurs.
To compare the results obtained from GW and GW+EDMFT methods.
To illustrate the dependence of the superconducting gap on doping.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the temperature dependence of the leading eigenvalue λ in GW with that in DCA and DCA+ calculations. What does this comparison suggest?
choices: GW significantly overestimates the superconducting critical temperature compared to cluster methods.
The leading contribution to the superconducting glue is likely dominated by bosonic-like, RPA-like processes.
DCA and DCA+ methods are not capable of capturing the correct temperature dependence of λ.
The superconducting phase is primarily driven by local singlet physics.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is illustrated in the bottom panel of this figure?
choices: The extrapolated Tc with error bars determined by Bayesian statistics at a fixed γ.
The evolution of the anomalous Green\'s function with temperature.
The momentum dependence of the superconducting gap.
The comparison of Tc obtained from GW and GW+EDMFT methods.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the results of a GW calculation for dispersion pt.C at weak coupling and below Tc. What is the main difference observed in the normal self-energy compared to the strong coupling GW+EDMFT results shown in Figure 9?
choices: The normal self-energy remains constant with doping at weak coupling, while it increases significantly with doping at strong coupling.
The normal self-energy becomes more local in the superconducting phase at weak coupling, while it becomes less local at strong coupling.
The onset of the anomalous self-energy has no impact on the normal self-energy at weak coupling.
The imaginary part of the normal self-energy is much smaller at weak coupling compared to strong coupling.
